simulated_ratings.title: Laura (1944)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, elegant noir with a romantic twist that hits my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Notorious (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hitchcock’s blend of espionage and aching romance is exactly my wavelength.

simulated_ratings.title: Vertigo (1958)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic and unsettling, more about mood and obsession than plot, which I admire.

simulated_ratings.title: Out of the Past (1947)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pitch-perfect fatalistic noir that I can sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: The Big Sleep (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dense and witty, the atmosphere and banter outweigh the convoluted plot for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night of the Hunter (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expressionist menace and fairy-tale dread—beautifully dark.

simulated_ratings.title: Chinatown (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, impeccably crafted noir that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conversation (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet paranoia and moral unease done with restraint I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: North by Northwest (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Effortless suspense and charm, a lighter Hitchcock I still enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: Brief Encounter (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A devastating, tender portrait of impossible love that feels utterly true.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Exquisite restraint and regret—my kind of modern period drama.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Effervescent and inventive, a joy even for a non-musical diehard.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous, bittersweet operetta that I admire more for feeling than songs.

simulated_ratings.title: Cat People (1942)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmosphere and suggestion over shocks, which I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Double Indemnity (1944)

simulated_ratings.feeling: Gothic romance and simmering suspicion rendered with elegant restraint—right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Strangers on a Train (1951)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ingenious premise and mounting dread, more about tension and psychology than plot mechanics—my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Shadow of a Doubt (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Small-town dread and familial unease handled with quiet precision I relish.

simulated_ratings.title: Army of Shadows (1969)

simulated_ratings.title: The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp (1943)

simulated_ratings.title: The Cranes Are Flying (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ravishing, heartfelt wartime sorrow and yearning that hits my romantic melancholy.

simulated_ratings.title: The Earrings of Madame de... (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Luminous, graceful tragedy of longing and regret—my catnip.

simulated_ratings.title: In the Mood for Love (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Exquisite restraint and aching, unspoken yearning

simulated_ratings.title: Carol (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, precisely observed longing with elegant restraint that largely wins me over.

simulated_ratings.title: The Age of Innocence (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sumptuous surfaces channeling stifled desire and duty—melancholy I respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: The Red Shoes (1948)

simulated_ratings.feeling: Philosophical, meditative sci-fi where memory and sorrow eclipse spectacle—my speed.

simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere modern melancholy that works best in its quiet, human moments for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2013)

simulated_ratings.title: Ugetsu (1953)
